prj:TechnicalJustification.prj:justificationText:
We ask for high-spatial resolution (0.7" CO(1-0) and CO(2-1) lines in central 30" of the six target galaxies. Our requested spatial resolution is driven by the need to clearly separate the NSC/BH system (which typically has a half-light radius of $\leq$ 10pc) from any circum-nuclear star formation and to map the CO velocity field down to scales of individual giant molecular clouds (GMCs) in the immediate vicinity of the NSC. The field-of-view of a single ALMA pointing will suffice, as it corresponds to about 1 kpc (CO(2-1), respectively 2 kpc (CO(1-0), at the distances to our targets, thus well covering the area of interest around the NSC/SMBH. We ask for ALMA imaging in Bands 3 and 6 to cover the CO(1-0) and CO(2-1) lines at 115\,GHz and 230\,GHz, respectively. Most of our targets have no previous CO observations. However, an IRAM 30m survey of similar galaxies \citep{Boker03b} has shown that the typical CO fluxes can be expected to be in the range 0.2-2 K km/s. As an example, we show in Fig. \ref{f:lines} the CO spectra of one of our targets \citep[NGC1042, from][]{Boker11}.
In the absence of any CO measurements for our other targets, we derive our sensitivity and resolution requirements from the IRAM 30m measurement of NGC 1042. For CO(1-0), we find a peak IRAM flux of 0.05 K (main beam) which translates to 0.24 Jy, and corresponds to a total gas mass of $\approx 3\times 10^6\,M_\odot$. Assuming that all the gas is contained in about 50 GMCs of 5x10^4 Msun each, we can expect a signal of ~5mJy per ALMA beam. Requiring S/$>5, the sensitivity requirement becomes 1 mJy: this takes approximately 1 h of on-source integration time in Band 3). A similar calculation for the CO (2-1) line (with a peak flux of about 0.4 Jy) yields a expected flux of about 8mJy per ALMA beam and thus a required rms of 1.6 mJy wich can be achieved in an on-source exposure time of 6 min in Band 6.
We expect no spatial variations per channel on scales smaller than about 15'' and thus request no ACA observations.

prp:ObsProposal.prp:abstract: Confirmed SMBHs with masses at or below $10^6 M_\odot$ are rare, likely because any signs of their activity are weak and very hard to identify in optical spectra. So far, only a handful of these "mini-AGNs" have been detected, mostly in the nuclei of low-mass, bulgeless spirals. The reasons for their inefficient growth remain unclear. One of the proposed explanations invokes ``competitive feedback" from a compact nuclear star cluster (NSC) which is found in all bulgeless systems with a low-mass SMBH identified so far. Here, we ask for ALMA observations of a small sample of NSCs, both with and without a confirmed SMBH, in order to investigate the properties of the molecular gas in the immediate vicinity of the nucleus. Our primary goal is to use the unprecedented sensitivity and spatial resolution of ALMA to compare the distribution and kinematics of molecular gas in systems with and without a ``mini-AGN''. In addition, the observations will also yield a high-resolution map of the line ratio $I_{21}$=CO(2-1)/CO(1-0), which may offer a new diagnostic tool to study the faintest AGN.

prp:PrincipalInvestigator.prp:organisation: European Space Research and Technology Center (ESTEC), European Space Agency (ESA)

prp:CoInvestigator.prp:organisation: European Space Research and Technology Center (ESTEC), European Space Agency (ESA)
European Space Research and Technology Center (ESTEC), European Space Agency (ESA)
European Space Research and Technology Center (ESTEC), European Space Agency (ESA)
Department of Theoretical Physics and Astrophysics, Granada University
